question.title: Tell Maven to look at alternative location for tools.jar
question.body:
I am trying to get a Maven build to work properly. I am on a VM workstation that has a jdk15 install.

I can only add files to my user directory.

The mule-app-maven-plugin-1.1.pom has a few issues that I have to resolve. I already set up mirrors in the .m2\settings.xml to deal with the HTTP repositories, but I've gotten stuck on the tools.jar.

The dependency in the POM is:

<dependency>
    <groupId>com.sun</groupId>
    <artifactId>tools</artifactId>
    <version>${java.version}</version>
    <scope>system</scope>
    <systemPath>${java.home}/../lib/tools.jar</systemPath>
</dependency>

I can snag a tools.jar and put it in my user directory, but I need to tell Maven to look there instead of the location coded into the mule-app-maven-plugin-1.1.pom. Is there something I can do in the settings.xml (or something else) to redirect this search to the location where I actually can drop a tools.jar?

answers.body:
What you are trying to do will not work with any JDK release newer than JDK 8 since the tools.jar file was removed in JDK 9. That may mean that mule-app-maven-plugin is not compatible with JDK 9 or greater. It would make also sense that it was never tested with newer JDKs since it is compatible with Mule 3.x only, which was compatible up to JDK 8 with its later releases. It may not work correctly with JDKs greater than JDK 8.

Also it is not recommended to JDK 15 for anything else at all since it was a short lived release. As a non-LTS version it was supported for six months until March 2021. Not even Mule 4.x versions claim to support non-LTS JDKs.

Conclusion: use the version of the JDK that the version of the mule-app-maven-plugin expects. Since it has been retired since 2019 there doesn't seem to be documentation available. I recomend to use the same version of the JDK that your version of Mule 3.x supports.

Update: the replacement for mule-app-maven-plugin is mule-maven-plugin. There are different versions for Mule 3.x and Mule 4.x. Mule Maven Plugin 2.3.x was the last branch to support Mule 3.x. Now it is EOL as all versions of Mule 3.x. For Mule 4.x there are newer versions. The recommendation is to use the latest version released that is compatible with your Mule runtime version. You can find them in the release notes.

Note: always use a JDK compatible with Mule and the respective Maven plugin. These products are only compatible with some JDKs (see requirements in the documentation and release notes) and were not tested with Non-LTS JDKs. Also the older Maven plugins may not work correctly with newer versions of Maven.

If you absolutely must use that plugin and it has a bad dependency, you can exclude the dependency.

See: https://maven.apache.org/guides/introduction/introduction-to-optional-and-excludes-dependencies.html

You could then possibly manually declare to include the tools jar in the pom yourself.

question_comments.body: If you would like to post that as an answer (update the local POM to drop 3.x stuff) I will mark that as correct. I cold answer it myself, but you should get the credit.

" Note that mule-app-maven-plugin was abandoned years ago."  This is what I needed to reset. I'm working with old, non-supported software and need to update it.  I do have a 4.9 runtime locally, while waiting for the 3.9 server infrastructure to get updated, so the problem seems to be mostly getting 3.x conventions out of my poms.

"The mule-app-maven-plugin-1.1.pom has a few issues that I have to resolve" looks you should be asking about those issues first. Otherwise this question feel like a potential XY Problem. Note that mule-app-maven-plugin was abandoned years ago. Having details about the issue would help to suggest other alternatives.
Can you try the below. mvn clean install -Djava.home=/your/new/jdk/path/

79567449.body: mule-app-maven-plugin was replaced by mule-maven+plugin. There are different versions for Mule 3 y Mule 4. I didn't understand your comment about Mule 3 conventions. If you mean you can use Mule 4, note that applications for Mule 4 are not backwards compatible with Mule 3. Also Mule 4.doesn't support JDK 15. Depending on the Mule 4.x version it supports JDK 8, 11 and/or 17. The latest at this time is Mule 4.9 that only supports JDK 17.
I'm stuck with JDK15, cause that's not up to me, but I'm not stuck with 3.x mule conventions.  I've been running with what I had and didn't know that the toolset was discarded.
